document.masterDocTitle: Review of Otites Latreille (Diptera: Ulidiidae) from Israel with two new species and notes on biology and behavior

, A. Freidberg (13, 1Ƥ), L. Friedman ( 2 Ƥ); Nahal Yehudiyya [Golan Jahudia],
1 .vi. 1971
, A. Freidberg ( 13 ). The holotype is pinned directly, is in excellent condition, and is deposited in TAUI.

Thorax : Color and vestiture: Black, gray microtrichose. Scutum with 1 medial and 2 lateral longitudinal stripes (anterior and posterior to transverse suture) with less microtrichia than on rest of scutum: Median stripe of brownish microtrichia extends from anterior margin of scutum to level of second posteriormost dorsocentral seta; lateral stripes with slight silvery microtrichia, anterior lateral stripe triangular, posterior lateral stripe extends from transverse suture to level of posteriormost dorsocentral or posteriormost acrostichal seta. Chaetotaxy: 2–3 supraalar setae, 1 postalar, 1 intra-alar, 3–4 dorsocentral, 1 acrostichal (sometimes with conspicuous setula between acrostichal pair), 1 proepisternal, 4–6 anepisternal, and 1–2 katepisternal setae present. Scutum, anepisternum, katepisternum and postpronotal lobe setulose.

Legs : Coxae and trochanters reddish-brown to orange; femora mostly brown to black, except apical 0.16 yellowish; tibiae usually with basal 0.50–0.66 yellow, apical 0.33–0.50 brown to black, seldom mostly or entirely brown to black; tarsi usually entirely yellow, sometimes with distal 1–3 tarsomeres brown to black. All coxae and trochanters densely gray microtrichose, remaining parts slightly gray microtrichose.

Abdomen : Brown to black. Syntergite 1 + 2 irregularly and slightly microtrichose basally and with transverse silvery-gray microtrichose medial stripe, medially about 1.5 times as wide as laterally. Tergites 3–5 with transverse silvery-gray microtrichose basal stripe, widened medially; tergite 6 in female with slight transverse silvery-gray microtrichose basal line. Non microtrichose areas shiny, delicately wrinkled in male, smooth in female.
Distribution. (Currently known only fron Israel ) Mt. Hermon 1000–2000 m . and Golan Heights.

Adult activity (in Israel ).
May to beginning of July.
Etymology. This species is named after Vitaly Dzuoba, a dear friend of the author.

Comments. This species is most similar to
O. lamed Schrank
, which differs in having vein R 1 entirely setulose, brown band along most length of vein Cu 1 , and cell br entirely brown. In
O. vitalyi
vein R 1 is setulose only along pterostigma, and cell br is brown at basal half and hyaline at apical half.
